user_review: Bocata is a gem. The dinner we enjoyed here was easily our most memorable meal in Montreál. The restaurant in located in one of the quaint little streets in the heart of Old Montreal. It's cozy but not cramped, with tasteful decór and elegant tables. They do get rather busy on evenings, so a reservation is likely a good idea. They have a rudimentary wine and beverage selection. The first appetizer to arrive is the | tuna otoro |, one of the daily specials. Ruby-red tuna belly, sliced thin, seasoned and torched lightly. I can only say that the otoro was life-changing. A moment of intensity, and then it vanishes in the mouth, leaving only the lingering taste of the fish, rich and fatty and luxurious. Addictive, stunning, magical. 10/10.My sister always says that nothing can beat a good | tuna tartare |. The second appetizer (and special) is Bocata's take on the dish, and it makes a strong case to prove my sister right. In a tartare, of course, the true flavor of the fish shines brightest, and this tartare does not disappoint. The tuna is clean and light and yet rich and flavorful, accentuated by the simple seasoning, hints of citrus and salt, topped with microgreen sprouts to balance the tuna's depth. It is elegance on a plate. 9.5/10| Patatas bravas | does not seem at all out of place on the menu, and yet the plate holds a few tricks up its sleeve. Rather than the thick crunch I expected, the  potatoes are subtly crisp and drenched in a light sauce. There is no heavy, greasy aioli here, the sauce is bright and complex and altogether lighter than any patatas bravas I've ever tried. 8.5/10Bocata also has a selection of fresh oysters, which we ordered, though unfortunately I didn't get to try them.Our final appetizer is the | gambas al ajillo |, shrimp served with a light broth and crusty bread. Argentinian shrimp are served supremely tender with a flavor reminiscent of lobster. The broth is fragrant and incredibly flavorful; hints of the guajillo chili, fruity with a hint of heat, garlic, pungent but mellow, parsley, butter, scallion, shrimp stock. Balanced, nuanced, and immensely comforting. I will dream about that broth. 10/10.Onto the mains dishes. Our final special of the night is the brilliant | tataki sandwich |, with bluefin tuna breaded, fried, and served between toasted white bread. The sandwich is delicately crispy, with additional texture from a red cabbage slaw. This is the meatiest tuna we try tonight, tender but with a bit of chew. Acidity to accent the fish's richness. Playful flavors deftly balanced, this sandwich is hearty and satisfying but light and absolutely delicious. 9/10.The next dish is the | risotto verde |. Creamy rice laden with peas, coriander sprouts, and briny, diminutive shrimp arrives veiled in mystery and a crispy canopy of chicharron made in-house. The tangy flavors of chimichurri (and is that tomatillo I taste?) collide with the velvety risotto to brilliant effect, but despite the vegetables and acidity present, the dish feels like it could use some fresh brightness. 8/10.Our final dish is the | bacalao a la vizcaina |, a dish of tender cod in red sauce with roasted fingerling potatoes. The fish is cooked until just flaky and seasoned very gently. By itself, it's actually rather bland, but it finds the perfect counterpoint in the piquant, vibrant sauce, brimming with fruity complexity and and just the right amount of spice. The roasted potatoes are creamy and well-browned, served with a secondary sauce with olive oil and fresh herbs. The dish has a quiet sort of appeal, perhaps not as exciting as some of the other dishes but easily as delicious, if not more. 9.5/10.The service is exceptional. The staff is friendly, attentive, and more than competent. Throughout our meal, I got the impression that our server was very interested in making sure we had a good time.In case you couldn't tell, I adore this restaurant. The food consistently maintains an incredible standard of quality, and the experience is top notch. Bocata is easily, heartily, heavily, wholeheartedly, highly recommended. 9.3/10 average.

Came here for brunch on a Saturday on our recent trip to Montreal. We were having trouble finding a good breakfast spot where there was something that we liked so we were happy when we stumbled upon this place. The inside is very cozy and inviting. I loved the whole decor of the place. It was very unique. The menu had a little bit of everything on it. I chose to get the french toast which was really great!My only complaint was that it was a little pricey, other than that I had a wonderful breakfast here with my friend.

Girls night ‍ everything BUT everything was #lickyourplate good!!! Squid ink shrimp  n chorizo risotto, lobster carbonara w oozing egg yolk and truffle salt, buttery iceland cod con tomate, grilled octopus and that semi-cooked  I'll be back @bocataoldmontreal so you can take all my  .

This is the first review I've written in over a month which is a long time for me to have gone without contributing something. Unfortunately, I've had some very difficult health issues that I am still struggling with, but hopefully I will be on the mend soon. Anyhow, enough about me and onto this wonderful little restaurant.The space is cozy with nice little mason jar lights and flowers at each table. The menu consists of a large number of snacks and appetizers which we can just group under the umbrella term of tapas. While they do have a small number of well known mains (mostly in the pasta/risotto family), we decided to build ourselves a tasting menu from the tapas alone.What ensued was just a lovely night of tastes and textures. Given my recent health problems, it felt good to be out with my wife alone for the first time in over a month, even if I was functioning at a reduced capacity.  I'm glad to say that Bocata rose to the challenge of making it a very enjoyable night.We started with the Spanish mainstay of the Bellota ham and the classic tomato bread. The ham was nutty and rich while the tomato bread was rich in garlic and olive oil with a thick spread of crushed tomato on top. I think the classic version of the bread usually has a thinner veneer of tomato seeds and inner jelly, but this bruschetta-like take on it was delicious nonetheless.We then moved on to the fried New Brunswick smelts served with a delicious aioli and a wedge of lemon. This snack is everything that is right in the world. You could taste the fish, the thin crispy batter, the wonderful seasoning, and the rich aioli in every bite. I could picture eating this at a seafood shack in Cape Cod.The dish of the night was the sockeye salmon crudo served in a raspberry gastrique with fennel and olive oil. The interplay of fresh raspberry combined with a hint of acidity elevated the tender salmon. The result was an ultra fresh and uplifting dish that was unexpected.The fish rillette served on toast with various toppings was the only dish that fell a bit flat for us. It was neutral and just didn't taste of very much at all. The burrata of the night was a Vietnamese peanut/sprout/sesame oil creation that was well conceived and absolutely delicious. It came with some pita bread. We finished every last morsel of the platter.To finish we paired an order of the shrimp in a garlic broth alongside the bravas potatoes. The shrimp was excellent, though not as well seasoned and delicious as a similar dish served at Ibericos on St. Denis. Nevertheless, without a separate reference point, these shrimp are objectively delicious and properly cooked. The bravas potatoes has a hint of spice to them, were boiled instead of fried, and are served in a reddish glaze. I would like to see them add a little aioli over top as is traditional with this dish.We ended the night with some port for my wife and at the recommendation of our friendly waiter, some yellow wine for me. (which is a first for me) It tastes like port but is nowhere near as sweet. I really enjoyed it. The Chef at Bocata is doing some interesting things and is clearly quite creative. For my taste, he might be straying a little too much from the traditional Spanish preparation of certain dishes. To his credit however, his experimentation works more than half the time. On a Saturday night, the restaurant was packed and everybody looked very happy. I count myself amongst these people and am grateful to have been out of the house and enjoying life with the woman I love.

What a magical experience. Bocata delivered on the food, atmosphere, and service. The oysters will blow your mind with the maple syrup toppings. I got the catch of the day which was snapper and it was cooked to perfection. Go to Bocata whether you're a local or just visiting.

Nice ambiance. Nice booths if you're a larger party. Very accommodating.Alexander Keith's Red Amber Ale - This is a refreshing beer, slightly reminiscent of a sour, but only lightly so.Orange Méchanique - This cocktail tastes primarily of Jack Daniel's with a touch of Aperol. Not a bad cocktail, but nothing mind blowing.Squid Ink Risotto - ONLY CAME WITH ONE SMALL SCALLOP which felt like a rip off, and the three measly shrimp were more skin than meat. However I did like that there were layers of flavor in this dish and each bite was flavorful and slightly different. The juicy tomatoes and chorizo pieces and micro greens all added their own touch to enhance this dish.Lobster Carbonara Tagliatelle - Good flavor and provides a delicious first bite, but the portion is definitely a bit on the smaller side.

We had dinner last night at Bocata for our last meal in Montreal before heading back to the US. The food was interesting and very good, service was great. Our waiter was friendly and very attentive at refilling our water glasses and offering more bread, wine, etc. For me Ambiance is an important thing at a dinner restaurant and Bocata definitely fulfilled my wish for that. Very charming decor.I would eat there again!

Just got back from Bocata and wow, was it an amazing experience. My boyfriend and I made reservations a week prior since we're here for thanksgiving break but we weren't sure what to expect but dang, we were blown away. From the service to the ambience to the food, everything was exceptional! If I lived here, I'd probably swing by at least once a week. From 17:00-19:00, they serve $1 oysters!!! Of course we had to try a few that were divine (we decided on 6 Quebec oysters). They weren't too strong in flavor, there was a good balance of salty and even a hint of sweetness! To start, we decided on the octopus which was the perfect bite to start off the night. I would definitely recommend this dish! For entrees, both us decided to split the lobster tagliatelle and the squid ink risotto. While we found the lobster dish to be a little more salty than we would've liked, it was still a solid entree however I can't recommend the risotto enough! It was so rich and creamy, I was so impressed. It also came with scallops which were so well seared and delicious. To finish off the night, we ordered the half baked cookie with bourbon ice cream. The ice cream took us by surprise with its strong flavors of alcohol but mixed in with the cookie, it was a bite of heaven.  If you're ever in the area, definitely swing by and give this place a try!

Found this gem on Resy. Loving the app so giving it the proper shoutout. Came here for an early solo dinner at the bar and it was exactly what I wanted. The specials were a salad and a fish; I listened but I already knew what I wanted. I went for the pata negra (read delicious ham) which comes with tomato toast (essentially bruschetta) and their signature lobster carbonara tagliatelle. The ham and bruschetta were magical. Tasty, crunchy, and everything that is right with food. The lobster carbonara was creamy (without cream from what I could tell and how it should be) and with the perfect egg sitting on top. My only comment was that it was a bit under salted but that could just be my taste. Overall I'd say this spot was pretty legit. I'd like to try some of the other dishes next time. Hopefully I'll come with more people to try it all.

In Montreal on vacay, we stopped by Bocata and glad we did. The dinner was absolutely delish! We got burrata to start with which came with amazingly toasted Pita. The dinner with lamb ravioli and Cod was super rich and wine selection was great too.Round that out with a great service and we have a 5 star place!

We made a reservation for bar seating (our fav way to dine) and had a wonderful night here. We started off with the patatas bravas, octopus, and cured mackerel. The mackerel was outstanding-- absolutely a delight. The octopus was tender and the patatas bravas were warm and soft when biting into it.Another star of the meal was the lobster carbonara pasta. I loved that despite the "carbonara" word, it wasn't your typical and generic white cream sauce. The brown base of the sauce was full of lobster flavor and essence. The raw egg yolk that came on top of the dish added to the taste after mixing it all in. We also shared the catch of the day, which was halibut. Wonderfully prepared as the fish was tender.Wine offerings have the option of a half or full glass. Cocktail menu is a printed label stuck on a glass bottle. How cool!The dining space is intimate and not too large, surrounded by stone walls. Makes for a great night out with friends or a date night.

This is a very cute brunch place in the old port. The food was quite good, but it's definitely overpriced. Eggs, bread, beans, and a bit of meat should never cost almost $20! My friend got a chickpea dish and that was also way overpriced. Those are cheap ingredients! You are basically paying to eat at a nicely-decorated place at the old port.
The oysters are to die for! A very good spot to take your significant other.  Got to try a 600lbs Blue Fin Tuna!! Definitely recommend.

Cute little place with a warm, semi-nautical theme. Waiter and barkeep, Charles, knows his stuff behind the bar.Appetizers were good, but need some work.  The peppers did not have enough cheese on them and the smelt were lukewarm. Chocolate cookie dessert was very good, warm and gooey like it should be.I will say that there were a lot of regulars there on the evening we went and the staff seemed to focus more on them, chatting, etc. than on visitors.

Had the greatest service and meal at Barroco!! The restuarant was quaint and cozy and the waiter was very attentive and helpful with a food sensitivity. Will revisit when I am in Montreal again for sure.

Just delightful. You know you are in for a special evening when the waiter is also one of the owners. A terrific selection of wines by the glass including unusual and off the scene selections. Pours are offered in 2 1/2 ounce and 5 ounce amounts, and sampling is encouraged.    Now let's talk about the food. Spectacular. They have a oysters, Pata Negra (that's cured ham from pigs who eat only acorns, is from Spain, and is rather pricey.... but they have it). Also wonderful fish and pasta.     After dinner, there are choices of port, Sherry, cognac, Calvados, Armagnac, and all the whiskeys and dessert wines you could imagine.  Wow !

We enjoyed a lovely meal at Bocata for out last night in Montréal. After a slight snag with our Resy reservation - apparently the restaurant did not have a record of it, even though I had confirmation - you might want to call to make sure. After that was sorted, we finally got a table and went on to enjoy our meal.I had a nice rosé by the glass, and there was a good selection of other wines as well. The menu is limited, and that is because everything is fresh and sourced as locally as possible. There were also some specials that our helpful waiter told us about.I went with one of the specials - a homemade pasta dish with mussels and tomatoes in a light sauce. It was heavenly! Everyone at my table tried it and enjoyed it.We all rotated our dishes so we could get a taste of everything. The Nordic shrimp salad was interesting - but ended up being very tasty. The carbonara was also good, as was the simplicity of the caccio e pepe. Everything was fresh and the ingredients high-quality.The waiter even gave us an after-dinner shot as a palette cleanser, and it actually tasted very good. Everything was thoroughly enjoyed! Bocata is a great, inventive, intimate spot in Vieux Montréal.

We arrived st 10:25 am. When we walked in we were told that they open in 5 minuets. At 10:30 we were seated along with 3 other tables. We placed our orders and got coffee. The food took a very long time. We finally got our meals at 11:20 considering that we were the first to arrive and that other tables seated after us got their meals and finished them before ours arrived the wait was too long. However, once the food arrived the did redeem themselves. I ordered the Trout Toast, which was bright and fresh and delicious. My husband ordered the Spanish omelette which was lack lustre but the salad that came with it was a beautiful butter lettuce dressed with a really good dressing. Our friend ordered their breakfast sandwich which was a beautifully crafted sandwich which tasted as good as it looked. For the 3 meals with 2 coffees it came to $50

I went to this small bar early tonight with friends for an early dinner. We had a crave for lobster so ordered lobster roll and lobster tagliatelle. They are amazing! The lobster roll is made from good brioche and fresh lobster. The slight sourness of the veggie inside is refreshing. The tagliatelle is very rich and full of flavor, with a lot of spinach and tomato. I love the fact that they put a lot of vegetables into both dishes, making everything light and enjoyable. The tres leches cake is also a marvelous desert.

We arrived in Montreal late, tired and hungry. We decided to stop in and we're glad we did. We ordered the Mushroom Cavatelli and it was delicious! Our server was great and attentive! Offered to make our kids a virgin cocktail which was very yummy according to our 10 year old. Music and atmosphere were entertaining and inviting.

Fresh Market Food- I had the bone marrow special appetizer and my family the burrata with pesto. I also had the lamb ravioli with aged cheese and wine reduction. The homemade pasta was to die fo! The service from Philipe was so welcoming, friendly and informative. I could eat here every night!
Best restaurant in the world! Ok, at least Montreal. Mitch and Victoria are wonderful. Excellent food and friendly small environment.  Highly recommend.

Fantastic meal and service all around.  I sat at the bar and was instantly greeted by the bartender who was friendly and helpful.Wines by the glass were nice (I tried 2 reds), $1 oysters were amazing.  Loved the New Brunswick pearls, and I had the special soup (white pea puree + dumplings) and the Lobster roll.Everything was delicious. I don't think I'd order the Lobster roll again because it wasn't outstanding or unique from what I get in New York.The big bonus is that the everyone at the bar was friendly, so we all had a nice chat amongst strangers.Thanks for a fantastic solo meal!

Had the pleasure of dining here on our last day in Montreal and it was a nice way to wrap up after another day of sightseeing.  The ambiance here is lovely.  It's best described as intimate/romantic and vaguely makes me feel like I'm in a grotto adorned with grey bookshelves and candlelight. It showcased an older European mix of french and spanish influences, complete with a cozy stone fireplace (although it was not burning when we were dining).We started our meal off with the Snow Crab Cake croquettes and the Tuna Tartare appetizers.   Both were pretty decent options.  I was glad that the chef was able to accommodate making our tartare without the Pata Negra since I don't eat pork.   Always a great sign that it's super fresh and made to order when you know it's not automatically mixed together.  Our crab croquettes were quite tasty as well; Enjoyed the crispy and light texture.  4/5For my main, I went with the Squid Ink Risotto and again, they were able to make it without the pork (chorizo) which was very much appreciated.  Good assortment of mixed seafood and definitely a pretty filling dish.  Seafood was cooked nicely but the rice could've used just a tad more spice.  Nonetheless, it was pretty good just the same.  3.5/5       Overall, a great stop to refuel before we made our way home.  Huge wine list btw if you love wine, both by the glass and by bottle.  Recommended if you're in the Old Montreal vicinity!

Why does this place not show up more on searches for brunch in Old Montreal? As a tourist looking for good places for brunch, every source just seems to default you to Olive and Gourmando. Tried to go there first but of course the line up is 45 mins. Walked down the street and we find this absolute gem with no line! At first we were skeptical, but so so glad we gave them a shot!Servers were friendly and helpful. But best of all the food was exceptional! The food here is expertly crafted and prepared. We're not talking Cora's here or Eggspectations. The breakfast sandwich here is one of the best I've had anywhere. It's that good. Perfectly cooked runny egg that erupts yolk the second you bite into it, with a great balance of acid from whatever the sauce was that was in it, all on the most delicate of buns (brioche?). House special pancakes were also crazy. Again, not just some regular housemade pancakes but these had some meringue pieces in it and fluffy whipped cream. Felt like I could've given them 4 stars because the portion sizes were on the small side but the prices were very reasonable.So happy to find my new favourite brunch spot!

We had dinner here. First off the look of the restaurant is very sexy- dark and intimate. The music however, does not go well with the atmosphere. They should definitely put on some spanish music instead of pop.The service was not great. We waited a long time for our server to get our drink and food orders. And another server came to give us the wine we ordered, that she served without even saying a word to us.Now, other than that- the food was absolutely amazing! A decent vegetarian selection- they offered to make us some dishes that typically contained meat- as vegetarian.We had the tomato toast, cheese selections, patatas bravas, tomato salad, asparagus salad (absolutely delicious) and the house made mozzarella with truffles.Will absolutely be coming back and would highly recommend as spanish-quebec fusion!

We came to Bocata the first night of my bachelorette party in Montreal -- and thank god we did because it was amazing! The service:1 word: VICTORIA. We were immediately seated as we had a reservation and Victoria our waitress greeted us. She was SO sweet and gave us some of the best wait service we've ever had. She really made it such a fun dining experience. We ordered shots at the end of our meal, Bocata covered a round and each time she took a shot with us. She helped my friends pick out a bottle of wine and was so patient with them. At the end of the meal we asked her if she knew any fun bars for us to go to and went and wrote a little list on paper and ever checked her Facebook to see what parties were happening that night. We actually used her list all weekend! ABOVE AND BEYOND!The food:Over all it was to die for. For appetizers we ordered the burrata, the cheese plate, and the asparagus (its in season right now in Montreal). All were great, but the burrata was outstanding. I ordered the sea bass, it came out crispy skinned and cooked to perfection on top of almost a purred hummus mixture. DELICIOUS. One of my friends ordered the crab and lobster squid ink risotto and O M G - out of this world. My other friend claimed "this may be the best dish I've ever had" referring to her lobster carbonara. Ambiance:Sexy and dark ... all the other patrons here were nice too! If you are in Montreal... make this reservation, you will not regret it!!
My absolute favorite was the Lobster Roll!! You must order! We also really enjoyed the cabbage. The server was knowledgeable, friendly and made excellent suggestions for cocktails.

Be charmed, wined and dined in a rustic setting that will warm you right up off the streets of Downqtown Montreal. Their selective menu is indicative of all well-done dishes that exude quality as well as presentation that appeals to all your senses. The owner Mitch and the entire staff are friendly, helpful and ready to share their thoughtful recommendations with their patrons. Service is on point with no empty glasses left unattended.**************Look for their Chef, JP Miron, on upcoming TOP CHEF***********Beef Tartare - we were so hungry we devoured it before taking any photos. Prime minced beef with licorice herb notes.Batatas Brava - roasted potatoes with tomato aioli...again devoured prior to photo.Cacio E Pepe - black pepper and black truffle pasta that would be the pride & joy of any authentic Italian chef.Sea Bass - Mediterranean style with perfectly crisp skin and Smokey accompaniment with fresh endive and thinly sliced green apple.Special of the Day - Seared scallops and a satisfying pea & mirepoix that is light yet hearty. I loved every bite of this dish.Donuts with dulce de leche - almost impossible that this doughy goodness is not cloyingly sweet given the cinnamon sugar and golden caramel sauce.Half baked chocolate chip cookie with house made Bourbon ice cream. Ice cream and melt in my mouth chocolate...just get it.This was an inaugural dinner to be remembered.#SommsofAnarchy

My husband and I came here on a bustling Saturday night. We had previously eaten at their sister restaurant next door, Barroco. That meal was so phenomenal that I wanted to try their other restaurant. It's a very charming, romantic vibe inside, great for a date. Food was very good, but not as phenomenal as Barroco. We had the devilled eggs, and mini burger to start, my husband had the squid ink risotto (they didn't have squid ink that night though, regardless, he enjoyed his meal). I had the home-made spaghetti with pecorino and truffle (delicious, and the highlight of the meal for me), followed by the lemon tart (pretty good), and my husband had the cookie with bourbon ice cream. Since I am pregnant, it limited my menu options, as there are a lot of raw items on the menu, and items which are barred from a pregnant woman's répertorie. But I based my menu selection based on what I could consume, and was not disappointed. Nice atmosphere on a beautiful street in Old Montreal.
Top rate in every aspect.  Excellent cellar.  Fresh vegetables from their garden.  Wonderful, classic dishes with some occasional innovations.Try it!

Dim, sexy, rustic decor...just the ambiance we were looking for on a recent night out in Montreal.After starting with a dozen perfect oysters and yummy shishito peppers, I went straight for the main event...a dish I had read about and couldn't wait to try: the lobster carbonara tagliatelle. Oh emm geee....that is one phenomenal pasta dish! Total foodgasm.Dave's steak au poivre, however, was tough and sinewy. The sauce was deliciously rich, but the meat was just...no. Didn't enjoy this one. When the waitress saw the mostly uneaten steak, she offered to bring us a better cut of meat. We said we were already full so she just comp'd our cocktails instead. Thanks?In the end, it was a great experience overall, but not quite as spectacular as its sister restaurant Barocco.

I have mixed feelings about this place, I'd give it a 3.5 but rounded it down because the cons outweigh the pros. The place is more of a dinner/bar place, but also opens for brunch. Because of that the inside is really dim, which wasn't a huge problem but just for brunch time they should really lighten up the place. Workers were nice, they were patient in waiting for our friend who was running late and in general friendly. The food was very tasty, at least for me, I really liked my French toast and the maple butter. Sweet and creamy. But charging $12.65 for a piece of bread with some butter, no matter how tasty, is pushing it a tiny bit too much. Portion is small and wasn't very filling, especially for a brunch. My friend ordered granola with yogurt and fruit, and that became the laughing stock of our meal 'cause the portion is TINY for a $9 dish. It was served on a plate, not a bowl, and there was like 2mm thickness to the layer of yogurt. My other friend's arctic char with avocado turned out to be the most value and also tasty, coming at $16, but even that's pushing it given the portion. It doesn't cost much to add some hash browns or some fruits to the side of these dishes. Just a bit more to make it tasty AND filling would make this experience worth it but it unfortunately wasn't.They do have really nice napkins though.

This was probably the best restaurant experience I've ever had. The whole vibe of this place was awesome. The owner was actually our server and he was amazing the entire night. The food is phenomenal and paired with amazing unique cocktail selections, how could you go wrong. If I could give it more stars I would.
Not that impressive. Cocktail is not really good. The plate doesn't have any signature taste, nothing really impress me :(

Stumbled in here late on a cold, rainy Wednesday night in search of warmth and nourishment. What a treasure! We enjoyed two tasty cheeses served with rustic bread and a clever carrot jam. We then went straight to dessert and ate the best cake we can remember - hazelnut, chocolate and cream layers. The textures and flavors were divine. We also ordered an apple pavlova that was beautiful and had a surprising and pleasingly tart topping. So...amazing food, friendly service and a cozy interior. It was such a wonderful surprise!

I would give this more than 5 stars if I could.We walked in on a Sunday night for a glass of wine.  We ended up with oysters and making a reservation for the next night.  When we came back, the bartender greeted us by name and shook our hands. We had the oysters again- they were fantastic both nights.  I had the lobster tagliatelli and my husband had the squid ink risotto.  Both were fantastic.  The wine selection is amazing- and the recommendations from the bartender were perfect.We loved the atmosphere- small and cozy, but not stuffy.  We enjoyed talking to other customers at the bar as well.

We wanted a delicious but laid back dinner, and we scored at Bocata! We were able to go without a reservation on a Wednesday night. We started with the special appetizer- panzanella. The tomatoes were delicious, but the dish was too salty. The buratta was very good- it's served with anchovies (which I personally don't like but my wife does!). The halibut special main course was amazing! Perfectly cooked fish over asparagus and ricotta- yum! Our server was super friendly, and the restaurant is so cute and cozy.

Loved this place.  Came here on our first night in Montreal.Ambience was great.  Loves the way the place is decorated.  Food and service was excellent.  Price was more than reasonable.  Would very much recommend.If I had to find something to criticize - I Would say that I wished the bread was warmed up.  But everything was SOOO good.I had the halibut special.  My husband had the lobster cabarena.  And we had the octopus to share.  Everything was delicious!

I made reservations online and, shameless plug, let them know I got engaged the day before. When my fiance and I came in, we got to choose our table. They even gave us free glasses of champagne to celebrate. The decor was cute and the food was fresh. I got the squid ink risotto which had a soft, luscious scallop and perfectly cooked prawn. The risotto was nice and salty (just how I like it)! My only suggestion is that I would have loved squid ink pasta but hey, beggers can't be choosers. My fiance had the oysters which came in three different types. The sea bass he had to end the meal had a nice crunch on the outside and a soft center. Come by and you won't regret it! But be prepared to relax, as the meals will come at a relaxed pace.

Food quality is good but over priced for what you get. We were shown to the bar after the host stated it would be a long wait for a table and we didn't feel very welcomed as one of the waiter stood in our way for quite some time as he was clearing the table and didn't even acknowledge we were trying to get by to the bar.  Once we got our food, that was it. No one even checked in on us. Quite a few tables opened up after we were seated so not sure what happened there either.  It was just OK.

I have to say that this was the best restaurant I ate at in Montreal. Our server was the best server I've ever come across (more like a friend I hadn't seen in a long time). She even gave up the restaurants Spotify playlist because the music was fantastic. The food was to die for. The oysters were hearty and delicious. Our server suggested a great bottle of wine. I can't say enough about this place. I cannot wait to take my family and friends back to this quaint restaurant. One of the best restaurants I have ever ate at!

Oh where to start, we loved this place! First, it's such a beautiful building and quaint space but the FOOD! Our server Jennifer was so helpful in suggesting meals and we loved everything she recommended. We shared the burrata appetizer, I had the catch of the day and my husband had the lobster carbonara, we also had the tres leches cake for dessert. DIVINE. Such a good experience and delicious food. Eat here!!

I intended to visit Barracco, next door, but as I walked by Bocata, the menu caught my eye as did a perfectly cozy seat for one at the end of the bar. They were happy to indulge me and I was magically met by the restaurant's owner, Mitch, behind the bar. He was very amiable and superbly knowledgable - takes great pride in his restaurant and staff. He set me up with a delicious glass of red wine and suggested the Tuna tartare accompany. The flavor combination was unlike any I have previously experienced. I just had to try a few bites of the Ricotta Cavatelli - several members of the staff stopped by to say how much they liked it and that they were excited for me to enjoy it. The kitchen KNOWS what's good. And they did NOT disappoint. My only regret is I didn't come hungrier. Bocata's atmosphere is cozy and their food is delicious. A wonderful date night, meal with friends, or - like myself - a treat for one. Ask for Mitch and Victoria.

This is is cutest date spot ever, and it reminded me of the Mediterranean. It's one of those places where the owner runs the front of house playing sommelier, bartender and server without missing a beat. There were other staff at the hostess desk and running food. They worked well as a team. Our meal was never interrupted wondering where dishes, drinks or condiments were. Gorgeous place, too.We started with a dozen Beausoleil oysters with Montreal Smoke Show jalapeño sauce on a couple. We got pata negra with traditional Catalan tomato bread and smelt, a delicacy anyone from Michigan or the Great Lakes knows.I ordered a sparkling Greek biodynamic white wine as an aperitif, and he recommended a bottle of one of their wines by the glass that was more consistent than organic wines can sometimes be. It complemented our meal nicely, as our main course was their lobster carbonara.The carbonara was light on the pepper, though they would add as much as you liked. The bacon was fat cuts of lardon. You got a nice piece of tail and a claw. Then the tagliatelle was arranged in a pretty birds nest with a quail egg in the middle that you stir in yourself at the table.For dessert, we had grapa and espresso with a delicious lemon meringue tart with pistachios and ice cream. It was a perfect and memorable meal, better than Le Serpent!

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!!!!I'm a person who has much attention to details, and I would say Bocata is perfect in them. The decorations, design, service, and even the washroom is perfect. The napkins are special, the bread basket is special, the seats are comfortable, the signature cocktail menu is on a bottle, there are paintings and a fake fish on the wall, there are different candles, there are books, dry ham and other decorations.For the food, it is also very good! We ordered an off menu special, a rib eye for two to share, the mushrooms are juicy and the rib eye was cooked perfect. The only thing is that I felt like there is a little more fat in the rib eye than there should be. We also ordered a squid ink risotto as a main. The risotto was perfect. We all loved it! Oh for the appetizer we had the Burrata. There was a lot, and we ate it with regular bread after we finished with the bread in the dish, and it was still so tasty. The pickled fish was great. For dessert, we ordered the carrot cake and the lemon pie. The waitress told us it was the last lemon pie. I would say the carrot cake was perfect. The lemon pie could be a little more sour. I would like it to be more sour.I love it! I really love this place!

I was excited to try Bocata since I loved barocco so much !  We went for dinner and sat at the bar on a Saturday. The decor was casual chic and very comfortable. The first thing that struck me is that this was a beautiful date restaurant with dim lighting and just a very nice vibe. We started with the octopus and potatoes  (great cook on the octopus but the potatoes were a touch underdone). I had the lobster carbonara which was delicious perfectly cooked lobster and pasta with great flavour. My boyfriend had the lobster boil dish and while the food was fresh and there was nothing wrong with it , he did say it lacked some spicing or something to make it stand out a little more. We also had the donuts for dessert which were nice and light and not overly sweet , they were a nice ending to the meal.  We had really great friendly service and they made a great wine suggestion for us. My only complaint is that I felt that it was a touch overpriced for what you get but definitely go in and try for yourself !

I stopped by at like 530 on a Tuesday. I heard this was a good place to try some wine so I figured I'd stop by and see if I could get a table or sit at the bar without a reservation. I believe they had just opened so I had the place to myself with a nice window seat. I asked the waitress if she recommended any good wine with the meal I was getting and she did. Let me try two of them and I picked my favorite. I ordered the lobster pasta dish (I forgot it's official name) and she came out with some fresh bread and oil for dipping. It was all very good. I'd definitely go again. She then recommended some desserts and I had the carrot cake with carrot ice cream. It was amazing! Best carrot cake I've ever had. I will note that I didn't have any problems getting a table without a reservation at 530, but several people started showing up at about 615 and were turned away because they were booked up. There are only 4 or 5 seats at the bar and those were all full. It was very good food and a nice vibe. It's a very small restaurant and very quaint.

It is good and the concept for the food is great. My problem with this place is that they put cilantro everywhere, not only when it is not called for, but they don't tell the customers n the menu. I belong to the 10% of the world population who doesn't like cilantro. If you're okay with cilantro then it is great.

Wasn't quite as enamored with Bocata as I was with its sister restaurant next door, Barraco, but nonetheless-this was a great experience.Fluke crudo was phenomenal. Mains were very good, pork chop and Lobster Carbonara. Great service, nice space. Feels like a slightly more casual and mainstream menu than Barraco next door, but both are worth trying.

Quaint, charming, romantic, adorable...are some of the adjectives I will use to describe this place. It reminded me of a bistro one might find in France.We stayed around the corner and dropped in for brunch! We were not disappointed!The staff was friendly and hospitable!Shout out to our waiter, Eli and the hostess!!!Our meals were delicious and creatively presented.They also served us warm, fresh baked bread.Can't wait to come back to Montreal and try this place for dinner!Merci

In old town and worth looking for.  It is small and even at 9 on Sunday we had to wait to sit at the bar-- get reservations. Love the intimate, friendly atmosphere. You can feel a great meal is coming and will be rewarded. Probably only 20 tables so when the bar tender offers two choices of manhattans you realize they are serious about their craft. Lobster carbonara with bacon and mushrooms served with a lightly poached egg you break and stir a s you are served to thicken the sauce. You have to try this dish!!!

Really liked it. I had the truffle pepper spaghetti and my wife had the pork chop. We also had the crap cake and the lemon Meringue tart. All full of flavour. Smaller portions. Price wasn't too bad considering the ingredients used. Very nicely lit. The music playing was the right volume and suited to atmosphere. They a few quirky things that I will leave for you to experience. It's a fun little place.
Great food and lovely atmosphere. I especially enjoyed the olive oil for the bread which learned is from Crete.

Quaint little European bistro in old town with the best braised bacon. Seriously.  I'm brunching and yelping at the same time.  Here's how we are brunching: fried eggs n mash sobrassada, eggs bourguignon (really amazing), Spanish tortilla and chickpea Shaksuka -- everything was magnificent. Snag a window table. Charming feel, vintage vibe, old books, and old brick. My kinda hole in the wall feel.  I'm beginning to fall in love with this city. Savor the whole experience with a bottle of champagne and freshly squeezed OJ. Merci #bocata Merci!

So this place is pretty nice, same owner as baroco next door but just not as quite as amazing.  Food was delicious and you can tell the ingredients are top notch. Good atmosphere and good ambiance as well!

The decor is very cute and quaint, I like the effort they put to make it cozy and authentic. As an entrée, we took the burrata. I was very disappointed as it was just the ball of cheese and a bit of olive oil. For the price it was, I thought they would add extra to it. Then we got the squid risotto and that was excellent! Highly recommend. As a dessert, we got a key lime pie and some donuts, they were fine. I wished they offered more elaborate options for their desserts. Lastly, the service was good.

Brought a large, loud, obnoxious, and picky group of co-workers here for dinner and the staff were all incredibly sweet and accommodating. The food was absolutely fantastic and the service was equally stellar. Thanks for putting up with us.

I was looking at places for dinner near Old Montreal and the concierge suggested Barrocco Restaurant.  Looking at the Menu outside my fiancé and I decided on Bocata ( next door).  We walked inside and I instantly feel the romantic vibe. There's deep brown wood ceilings, bookshelves with old books, a brick wall, dim lighting and candelabra's and candles on the tables. They transformed an old book into the drink menu, very cute. There's an automatic wine bar that dispenses the Wine and keeps the temperature regulated and air-tight, as well as perfect pour.  The wine list on a chalkboard, they serve by the glass and half glass as well as bottles.The hostess sat us near the window and I asked her about recommendations. The hostess was very friendly and pointed out the warm Octopus salad among other delicious apps.The waitress offered sparkling or flat water. We ordered the warm Octopus salad to nibble on and ordered Steak and Mediterranean sea bass as our mains.The Octopus was cooked to perfection, not chewy at all, and a delicious flavour. even though I knew it was a warm salad it still was surprising to take a bite of a warm salad dish, it was Memorable.The Steak was tender , no need for a knife, and came with a Beet purée. It was tasty but really such a tease size, it was the size of our app. I felt sorry for my Man he Eats, and the waitress didn't mention the Entrees are Very small plates.   The Mediterranean sea bass looked more like a snapper *see pictures, and was by far the smallest piece of Sea Bass I have ever ordered.  It was accompanied bySweet potato purée and had crispy pieces of sweet potato in it, out of this world flavourful. There was also some fish roe on top. Again small, we should have ordered two more dishes! Yes I asked for more country bread for my Man, and he still left hungry.  We had a nice romantic dinner, the ambiance was definitely there, good looking diners, the food delicious, it's just disappointing to leave a Restaurant hungry.    If there was a little more food its an easy 5 star restaurant.

THIS place is the best. Now my favourite spot in Montreal. We just spent a few hours there on a quiet Monday night. We were the first to arrive for dinner at 6:45 PM and it filled up by 8PM, which is a good sign for a Monday night. The food is A+++ ridiculous. We ordered a bunch of things from the menu over 3 courses, which was presented in perfect sequence by our wonderful host/server Frederic. He and his co-workers know everything about the menu and wines. They advise, suggest and recommend perfect combinations for us. In short, the service is impeccable and the food is as good as we could ever desire.  The atmosphere is lovely. The decor is gorgeous with intimate, unpretentious, ecclectic surroundings. This is the kind of place where you feel like you have the best people taking care of you with pure love. I'll try to remember what we had: Patatas Bravas. "How do you make potatoes so delicious." said my dining partner. Followed by a nice selection of oysters with handcrafted side sauces. Yum. Shishito peppers & pata nega  (melt in your mouth Iberico prosciutto), burrata with boquerones cheese truffles, and the famous lobster boil for main course. 3 hours of decadent pleasures. We washed it all down with a smooth Knock on Wood Chardonnay from Oregon. The perfect match, as suggested by Frederic. For dessert we had donut holes with dulce de leche. No words. We highly recommend this place. Wonderful vibe, great staff and superb food. This is as good as it gets in Old Montreal.

Great food, great service. We had the duck confit salad and the roasted duck magret. Both were brilliant, the salad being near the best we have ever had.While staying at the Old Montreal the location is also very good. Service couldn't have been better!

Nestled along the famous Rue St. Paul, is a quaint restaurant where you will no doubt have a fantastic meal.Look for the lit up "B" and you will find, Bocata, a Spanish influenced bistro.With only a few tables, be sure to make your reservation days in advance.Bocata offers small plates and some entrees that are large enough to share. We started with the crab cakes. The order comes with only 2. They were very flavorful and make with true crab meat. Very pleased these were not heavy on mayo, which is what you see a lot.We also ordered 15g of the cured meat. It reminded me of the jamon in Spain and Paris. Melts in your mouth!For our main course, we shared the veal chop served with gnocchi. Wow! This was amazing. The veal was so tender. And the gnocchi was simply wonderful.Finally, we ended with the frozen nougat. It was nice and not too sweet.

I thought long and hard about this one, the restaurant is a great spot for a romantic evening. The decor, setting, seating and lighting are all great.The service is very friendly and the wine list is fantastic.I'd like to see fewer cocktails with Jack Daniels but that's just me, however the food was where it lost stars. The oysters were a great start, nice choices, meaty fresh expertly shucked.The tuna confit has a larger than needed garnish of chevril which isn't able to be eat (a large sprig doesn't lend itself to being eaten) and I wasn't sure how to be eating the chips and sour cream and caviar with the tuna. Ended up eating the tuna, then eating chips and very fancy dip. It came off as trying a bit hard.The octopus and potato dish was pretty tasty, the octopus was well prepared but the sauce needed lemon adding that (and it could have used a bit of heat) made it much better but it really did need an acid on the plate. We had lemon for our water not the dish itself.The main was a lovely well prepared roasted sea bass, which for reasons I can't understand had very bitter endive topping (it's on the menu but it was leaves, with an apple slice inside) the risotto was lentil based (I didn't ask about that as I just assumed rice so that one is on me I suppose) but it was just a very odd dish that again seemed to be trying a bit to hard. Service however was excellent and it was a nice spot, depends on what you are looking for.

Adorable and charming decor in and out. Alway love the "B" sign outside. Tiny restaurant and very warm feeling inside.  Great staff from the hostess to the server. The food was awesome. Not in love with the appetizer we had (albacore tartare) but the main dishes were amazingly delicious.  Tartare was fine but something is missing...looks pretty though. The Mediterranean Sea bass was a bit different than normal crispy skin at other restaurants. It's skinless and on a pile of shiitake mushroom, spinach n sweet potato purée.  The whole thing was so soft and yummy. Every single bite. And the fish size was more than generous. Like the whole fish with 2 big filets. Thyme roasted milk fed veal chop. Just the name itself is divine and the dish was amazing. Perfectly cooked chop and the homemade gnocchi on the side was delicious as well. Really didn't expect such awesome meal from this place but was pleasantly surprised. If the tartare was better, would give this place 5 stars. Wish I could go be it 4.5!!!  The limoncello glacé deader was also awesome too.
This is a great restaurant with awesome food and a great bartender! The catch of the day had an delightful combination of flavors and hints of all fresh ingredients! Highly recommended!
I used to like this place a lot but unfortunately the food this time was just ok. The service is bad. The waiters aren't friendly and they take a while to seat you. I don't think I'll be back.

A lovely late meal here. Our server, Frederic, was a delight and extremely knowledgeable about the food and wines and he helped make our meal totally enjoyable despite a boisterous table seated near us.

Food ***** Excellent Veal ChopWine ***** Very niceService ***** GreatAmbiance *****  The Bocata is a charming place to dine.  Love the vintage rock music.  Overall, it was an excellent dining experience.

First time in Montreal, stumbled upon this place by accident for dinner with my family. The ambience and decor were adorable and intimate. The food was incredible and so fresh. We shared fried smelts as an appetizer (must try) and I had a glass of Riesling and the thyme roasted seabass as an entree. Service was great as well, would be a romantic date spot!

Was here for conference in Montreal and found this place by accident. Was having dinner next door and the restaurants shared the washroom. The vibe was interesting enough we returned the next night for snacks and drinks. Would have to say that this was an incredibly fun evening. The snacks were amazing and the drinks on point. They have an extensive wine menu per glass our server pointed us in the right directions all night. She made our evening. Was so good I returned for brunch the next morning. Strongly recommend coming here.

Awesome foodGreat ambienceAttentive serviceThe main course took longer that it should've for such an exclusive restaurant with limited seatingThey world be well served by doing away with a couple of 2 sweater tables. I could've as much been a part of the conversation and meal of the adjoining table as I was my own

Not fussy but focused on good southern France Mediterranean food and drinks. Staff are oh so friendly and helpful. Simple fried smelt to much on with the drinks. Creamy Squid ink risotto with nice whole shrimp and scallops. I had the rib eye cap which had a deep roasted earthy flair with the mushrooms. And the Lemon curd with the luscious marshmallow meringue is so unique yet so comforting. Of course the people watching is fun especially later as they walk down the street.

On a recent rainy Sunday in Old Montreal, we ran into a pretty wine bar with really nice florals out front to dry off and stepped back in time into a welcoming cafe offering smiles, drinks and good food. We felt very lucky! The atmosphere is rustic & homey ala 100 years ago as bars were in the 1970's (not newly done over and "quaint" or "kitschy" as century old places often are today).  From a cozy spot at the bar where we could people/decor watch, we enjoyed a toddy & a mimosa with light brunch plates. My husband ordered something bacon-y and I had smoked salmon piled so high I couldn't finish. As I said, a lucky find for us. I recommend visitors note the address & make Bocata a destination during  a tour of the old port.  ps, if anyone knows the connection with "Somms of Anarchy", I'm curious.

Bocata is a very cute and cozy restaurant on a very cute cobble stone street. The man friend and I thoroughly enjoyed our dining experience here. We came in for a late dinner on a Monday night and sat at the bar. Both of the servers were very nice, personable and accommodating. The food was really good and they have a pretty decent wine selection. (loved their wine dispenser) We ate:Pata Negra de Bellota - omg I love Jamon Iberico. It's sooo tasty! Just the right amount of saltiness and sweetness from the meat....Duck confit salad with a crispy egg - the man friend loved it so much he didn't even save a bite for me! sighLobster Carbonara Tagliatelle - came with tomatoes, spinach and an egg yolk in its shell. This was so delicious! The egg yolk added a nice creaminess to the pasta. The veggies added some brightness to the dish and there was plenty of lobster mixed in with the pasta. The portions here are not big. Most of the restaurants we dined at in Montreal had much bigger portions but this was just enough for the both of us. We both left happy and satisfied and headed to Le Lab - recommended by the servers.
Beautiful little restaurant, warm antique decor, friendly staff, delicious food and coffee... great find for an intimate dinner night!

This place was INCREDIBLE! We were a party of 5 it's and the night started great with Hendricks and tonic. Oysters and bone marrow apps were also great. Our waitress warmed up to us eventually and had awesome recommendations for the rest of our night. Dinner we tried the lobster carbonara, halibut and squid ink risotto, all were perfect. The atmosphere is also awesome, very cozy and intimate experience. Will absolutely go back next time we're in Montreal.
Service was very good. The inside of the restaurant was decorated well. It is a nice place to go for the food/surroundings.
Bocata was amazing! The atmosphere was really cool and the food and service was amazing! Will definitely go back!
We eat here every time we come to the city. Great location, tasty and fresh food, service is good and it's go a cool atmosphere. We love the lobster rolls and they have a great selection of wine.

We dined here for our 15 year wedding anniversary. Good thing the weather was bearable because the restaurant was open air & I wasnt expecting that otherwise I would've dressed a little lighter. The service was fantastic! The girl that waited on us was very informative and attentive. We were welcomed with two glasses of bubbly. We ordered the burrata w/ white anchovies & shaved summer truffle. We didn't taste a hint of truffle. The serving was plenty but I wouldn't order that again. My husband order the pork chop & I ordered the lobster carbonara. The portion on the carbonara was pretty small which I should watch my portion size anyways but with the small amount of lobster in it (I counted 3 small pieces) it shouldn't have been $30. Each dish we had the sommelier paired wine by the glass which they had us sample first before selecting & that was great! For dessert we had the lemon meringue torte, the lemon filling & meringue was great but we didn't care for the puff pastry it was on, it was too hard to cut through. All in all I loved the ambiance but would maybe come back for a bottle of wine to share with appitizers & dessert.

I loved eating here and would definitely come back. It's the only restaurant I've eaten at in Montreal, and I feel even if I go to many others, this one would still be on the top of the list. I loved the ambiance inside - wood-paneled, warm, cozy, and it felt like I was eating inside someone's study or library (sans dust - a clean, and well-kept library ;))My co-worker and I shared all of the seafood dishes in the "Fresh Catch" section. My favorite was the Lobster Tagliatelle, she liked the Squid Ink Risotto best. They seem to rotate through dishes seasonally (awesome sign of a great restaurant!), because the menu online has changed since I visited a week ago.Lobster Tagliatelle ($23) - The version I ate had cherry tomatoes, lobster, spinach, and the yolk that came in its shell - it was all so delicious. A must-have dish in my opinion. Not salty, very flavorful, and not too skimpy on the lobster.Mediterranean Sea Bass ($17) - This had wild mushroom, spinach, vanilla infused sweet potato purée. The fillet of fish was a bit on the thinner side, but all the side veggies complemented the fish very well. It was a sweeter dish thanks to the sweet potato. It was good, no complaints, but I probably wouldn't get this again because I'd like to try other things.Squid Ink Risotto ($19) - Really enjoyed this dish. Risotto was cooked perfectly and it had nice pieces of seafood and scallops inside.Molten Chocolate Cake ($9) - Perfectly baked so that the entire texture of the cake was soft. It was not a hard cake with a runny middle, but almost just a soft, fluffy, chocolate cake. Perfect. I could have eaten an entire one (or two) of these, it was that good.All in all, a delicious meal. The 3 dishes plus dessert was the right amount of food. I highly recommend splitting dishes if you come so that you can try a little bit of everything. With our 2 drinks, the total bill was a little over $100.

Ate here on our last night in Montreal, wish i had tried it sooner! Ate a few other places including one of the more hyped up spots in the area, which came in slightly under expectations. Bocata was amazing! The food was delicious, the ambience was spot on, music selection was great! ... but let me get to the food.... Had the fried smelt, first time trying this, were delicious, perfecr with the spritz of lemon and then a mayo dip, could have had more! Hubby had the oyster special and loved them. The octopus a gallega was tender, and wonderful. But the highlight for me was the squid ink risotto... EAT THIS ... i could have eaten this for every dinner... it was rich and delicious, with a little smokiness from the spicy chorizo, tender little baby squid tentacles, peas, and baby cilantro sprinkled on top. The prawn and scallop served on top were cooked to perfection! Get this, you wont be disappointed!!!! The only downside here was that they were out of the crispy chicken skins for the night, which i was dying to try, but they must be good if they ran out! 5 stars, will recommend to anyone who takes the trip out to mtl. Oh, and make a reservation in advance, and if you cant, download the DINR app to score last minute reservationa from cancellations if you cant find something!

Stumbled upon this place last week while I was Montreal for business. Cool place- atmosphere is really neat and inviting. I sat down at the bar and said "looks like a nice place to have a few cocktails". The bartender quickly came back with "sorry, if you want to drink you also have to order food, it's the law". Hmmm ok. I wasn't planning on eating, but this was a blessing in disguise. Started out with a RYE Manhattan. She made a really good drink. I then ordered the lobster and ham carbonara. YUM. SHIT WAS GOOOOOOOD. lobster was super tender and the ham added a nice salty taste. I would for sure come back here for a meal!And they give you your bill in an old book....

I made reservations here about 2 weeks prior to my visit - a late Friday night dinner. I wasn't quite sure what to expect, seeing as how the majority of the other restaurants I'd looked at in old Montreal were completely booked for any reasonable dining hour on the night in question. Suspicious...Well, much to my delight, this place was great. A very small, intimate environment, made all the more interesting with authentic "cracked" brick walls fitted with candles, complete with running wax spillover. Very cool. In short, a great  backdrop for a night out with the wife.The service was great, our waiter was definitely on his game.There's clearly an emphasis on seafood when it comes to the menu, so I decided on the warm octopus salad, and the squid ink seafood risotto. Both were prepared perfectly.They also have a very good selection of wines by the glass, which seemed to me to have been curated very specifically, which is atypical of most restaurants these days, so extra marks there. Overall, a great dinner with great service. If I lived near here I would definitely treat it as a go-to for casual dinners with family and friends.

The restaurant was quite good. We ordered many of the snacks & appetizers with the best being the fromages de Noyan and Pata Negra De Bellota. I ordered the Loup De Mer Roti. It was probably the mostly expertly made sea bass I have ever had the pleasure of eating. The ambience of the restaurant is really quiet lovely.

One of our best meals in Montreal was at Bocata.  This hole in the wall place, which is a bit dark and warm in summer, served up some creative and interesting food.  Plus, the service was nice and some great wine was to be had.As one of the other reviewers pointed out it is best to approach Bocata knowing what you are getting into, which I agree with.  They do serve wine in two sizes by the glass and the prices are a bit high, but get a bottle!  Tell the sommelier what you like, and he'll recommend a bottle.  This is what we did and got a lovely spanish wine that we hand't had before and now I'm dying to find. Our server was very nice, informative, pleasant and just plain did a good job.  The food is served tapas style, small plates, but are a bit different than traditional spanish tapas.  No patatas Brava for example, but don't let that stop you, there is some good flavors and creativity here.  We started with some Iberian Negra ham, a real pleasure and hard to get in the states so this was a good treat.  The bread served with it was out of sight.  We also had the heirloom tomato salad.  Fresh and amazing flavors.  Not too heavy and the flavor of the ingredient really showed through.After that we had the beef cheeks, the halibut & mushroom duxelle, and and the veal with manchego.  The beef cheeks were tender, amazing complex flavors and the roasted shallots were a nice counter point.  The halibut was one of the best things I've had in a long time and probably one of the reasons I'm giving them 5 stars.  The fish was cooked perfectly, the mushrooms Devine and earthy, and the broth it was served in was a bit of genius and worked so well with the flavors.  The veal, well the veal was a disappointment.  The meat was cook properly and fine, but the polenta was not what I think of as creamy polenta and the manchego's flavor was lost in the polenta.  This dish needed some work or maybe my expectations were too high because of what came before.  5 dishes was more than enough for dinner for two.  I would rather have 2 or 3 bites of something amazing than a whole plate of one thing, so Bocata fits the bill for me.  Can't wait to come back and eat there again.

This charming tiny restaurant is located on a narrower quaint street in Old Montreal and has great ambiance.  It's very eclectic, rustic in style and candlelit. There is a small bar with half dozen bar stools or so and the dining area has two curved booths and maybe 10 tables. The gentleman who greeted us and actually served us was friendly and provided good service.  We ordered a bottle of Montelpulciano d' Abruzzo and the fried smelt to begin. The smelt were very small in size, 3" long, lightly fried and served with a lemon aioli. They were light and tasty with a little crunch. I was brought back to my childhood and my mom and grandma making smelt.  For dinner, my husband had the veal chop. It was cooked medium rare and a nice-sized portion. The veal was served with homemade gnocchi. My husband devoured it and said is was fantastic. I had the lobster carbonara tagliatelle. The sauce was a very light carbonara, not made with heavy cream.  This dish had lobster, bacon, shallots, sundried tomatoes and egg. The menu said egg yolk in its shell, but it wasn't served that way; there was an egg on top of the pasta minus the shell presentation. This dish missed the mark for me even though there were large pieces of lobster. Being 100% Italian, I expected a tastier dish. The bacon or pancetta was wilted and could have been cooked crisp for texture and the dish lacked Parmesan cheese and salt. I think if there was cheese in the carbonara or grated on top, it would have elevated the flavor.  After dinner, the check was presented in an old book which patrons write notes in. A cute touch and I added a note, too.  All in all, I would recommend this small bistro even though my entree was lacking. Everything else was good and the atmosphere was unique. In looking at photos of the lobster carbonara from reviewers here and on Trip Advisor, it seems this dish varies in presentation.  I think it may be a dish to give a second chance.

Bocata ranks as one of my top dining experiences of all time. The food was fresh and flavorful, and the drinks perfectly crafted. But what made Bocata so special was the rustic, old world charm that immediately engulfs you as you step through the door. Please do not pass this up, let yourself get lost in this fantastic little place.
Ambiance 5, Service 5, Food 3.  everything's was pretty creative but mostly salty , menu not clear and not many options to choose from.
Where do I begin? Our server, Victoria, was great! She recommended a delicious wine. The apps and entrees were delicious. The dessert, lemons curd was outrageous. Really worth a visit

Floor staffs constantly check the status of each table and carefully service food and drinks. Quality of food is pure French but they line variety of south of France and mediterranean things in extremely high quality. Ribeye with mushroom was perfectly cooked as medium rare, and synchronized with the other dishes. Over all, just amazing restaurant.

Truly outstanding meal.After a 5 year hiatus, I returned to Montreal looking for some great meals and Bocata was an unexpected surprise hit.  The environment was homely and romantic.  Both my wife (a fish lover) and I (a meat lover) enjoyed the food thoroughly.  We also recommend Le Club Chasse et Peche and Au Pied de Cochon but found Chez l'Épicier to be past its prime.

Bocata is a most charming and delightful Tapas restaurant, which is located in the heart of Old Montreal on beautiful rue Saint Paul West. There are three languages spoken at this establishment which is seriously very helpful. Bocata is a wonderfully inviting and charmingly decorated restaurant in a 200+ year old building. When you walk in, it is like stepping back in time, 200 years!  It has a charm and warmth from the old world stone, wood, brick and gorgeous hand crafted floors. Then there's the food! Oh my... Absolutely done to perfection! And the staff is so knowledgeable about their cuisine as well as their specially selected wines. I've been there many times during business travel and I am always amazed at their culinary innovations. I usually chose the staff recommendations. If you only have a weekend to spend in Montreal, this is a "must go to place..." especially if you like spectacular food and service! Bon appétit!Ivan M

The food here was fantastic, appetizer of mushrooms on French bread with caramelized onions topped with truffles. Main course of a lobster roll and clam chowder. Glass of red wine. Excellent and friendly service; very professional. Absolutely loved it!

I think there are better places in town if you want a full, hearty meal, but I can't imagine many places better than Bocata for grabbing a great glass of wine, sharing some small plates, and pretending you're in France (without the jetlag).We had basically all of the charcuterie, and also had the octopus salad, and burrata, and they were superb (but when is burrata not superb?...).  The atmosphere here is great, especially on a nice night when the windows are open, and it's great to stroll around old Montreal after the meal.Tres bien!Food: 4/5Value: 4/5Service: 4/5Atmosphere: 5/5

Very nice servers in a warm, romantic setting. The food was delicious, the music fun, the vibe enchanting. Busy enough to feel energetic, but without the tedious wait required at other nearby establishments. Highly recommend it.

Tonight we made the rookie mistake of going out into Old Montreal looking for dinner without making a reservation first. Luckily, Bocata had a few seats at the bar and were able to serve us anyway.We started out with some drinks and if I were to split up my rating, I would definitely give the bartender and the drink 5-stars. I ordered the bloody goblin which was absolutely outstanding. I typically don't like sweet drinks too much but this drink had the perfect level of sweetness with an herbal aroma to compliment it well.For an appetizer I had the duck salad which was also outstanding and deserving of five stars. For the main dish, we all ordered the veal which was tasty but not at all deserving of the price tag it came with. The meat was pretty tough and not really anything to write home about. I would give the veal two and a half to three stars. I should not have ordered dessert because I already ate way too much but I did anyway and had a rich chocolate lava cake with homemade raspberry vanilla ice cream. The ice cream was pretty delicious but the lava cake was okay. I probably would have enjoyed it all a lot more if I wasn't already stuffed.Overall, I was happy with this place and I would be happy to return here. I'm happy to add this to my list of nice Montreal restaurants that are within walking distance of my hotel.
Quaint and cozy place.  Food was good, great service. Loved the European feel. Great wine selection.

The food was excellent. My friend got the lobster carbonara and I had the Loup. We were quite uncertain about which wine to have so the serveur had us try some (we had different one, because different food) and I must say it was on point.Make sure to come in early so there is some of that chocolate cake left (we didnt have the chance to try it but I'm sure it is as amazing as the rest!)We will be back !

Came for brunch.  I did not have a reservation but they found me a seat at the bar. My choice (egg sandwich) was not available because the bread did not arrive today. As I waited for my new order, I saw half a dozen sandwiches sail by to other patrons.  My eggs on mashed potatoes was delicious, despite the sausage in the middle being cold. The side of bacon was stunning, with the perfect drizzle of maple syrup. Ambiance is fantastic and sitting at the bar feels comfortable.  I'd come back to try dinner but my experience doesn't put it top of list.
Great location, cool vibe.  The waiter was very helpful.  I enjoyed the food and the wine, particularly the lemon tart which was out of this world.  Highly recommend!

Small and unpretentious. A low keyed, friendly stop. Great service. Bocata's signature dessert-a lemon tart, stole the show. We started with tasty smelts, batter fried. The lobster tagliatelle was a tad over- sauced but beautifully presented. Any and all concerns melted at dessert. The tart was gorgeous to look at, divine to bite into. Not to missed, only to be remembered! Merci, Bocata!
Stumbled in here searching for brunch and it was a hidden gem. The ambience and decor were very cute and comfortable. The food was diverse and creative for brunch and portioned perfectly.

I found this little gem on Yelp - so a huge thank you to my fellow Yelpers for guiding me here.   This is a quaint, hip place with amazing food and great wine.   I came for the octopus and the oysters - and they were both fabulous.   The octopus was the star - it was phenomenal.   You must try it!   I'll be back next time I'm in town.

Love this cozy restaurant conveniently located 3 blocks from my house. Needless to say that I'm there quite often. It's romantic, perfect for a date (sit by the fireplace) or keep it casual and sit at the bar. Food is delish and service is great.

Went there on a Wednesday night prior to a show.  Honestly, I picked this place due to the yelp reviews and that they had smelt.  I missed having it back home and wanted to try it.  OH MY, it is just as good as it is at home.  Also ordered the Squid Ink Risotto. Very good but the greenery on the top was over powering.  Great location, nice walk from our place.  Interior was nicely done and very quiet.
Beautiful and charming. Had Pata Negra to start, always delicious and expensive. Lobster carbonara and halibut special were delicious. Nice beer and wines to choose from

Delicious delicious delicious!!!! This place is an absolute must stop and eat in montreal. the restaurant is small but so cute! We sat right by the window. The food was amazing! The sea bass, wonderful. The squid ink risotto, a must! Great lasting impression!!

I don't think I've given a five star review before.  Ever.   But this place warrants it.  The thing that makes it great is that the staff seemed to really care about the work they were doing and the food they brought out.   At our table, for apps we had a special duck confit salad (which seems like it's a fairly common special), and fried smelt. Both were awesome in their own right.  Especially the salad, which may qualify as life-changing.  Entrees were roasted cod, squid ink risotto with various shellfish, roasted seabass with a creamy sweet potato topper, and a basic kids pasta, which in reality was a tasty tagliatelle pomodoro. Excellent wine selection, if a bit pricey.  We had a few off the by-the-glass menu which were delicious.  To seal the deal, we had the chocolate lava cake and tiramisu.  Both were delicious.  We finished off with some Taylor Fladgate 10 year old Porto, which is always nice.  A decent selection of after-dinner drinks if that is your thing.      As others have written, the portions here are not big.  They are appropriately sized to give you a delicious and fulfilling meal.  If you want to strap a feedbag on your face, you can try Buffalo Wild Wings or something.  We took our time and we never felt rushed.  On a Sunday night, they turned away at least 25 people.  They could've tried to move the tables, but that never happened.
This plane was delicious. I had the octopus. They were child friendly.  We brought our friends kids with us and they had spaghetti. The wine was good. We enjoyed our experience thoroughly.

Went with my wife...Nice, quaint, well decorated, and great experience. Extremely well informed staff and excellent homemade food!!We had the the Smoked Salmon and Piquillo appetizers and the Seabass and Lobster Carbonara mains. Everything was delicious.

"Omg!!" I believe those were our exact words after our first bite of the Bone Marrow! We stumbled upon this place while walking around Old Montreal and couldn't be happier. The hostess made room for us even though we didn't have a reservation and was extremely inviting. We ordered the bone marrow, beef carpaccio, and the octopus. The bone marrow was insanely good!!!! So good in fact that every time we eat marrow we will now have to compare it to their version. I would definitely order the beef carpaccio again but unfortunately I cannot say the same about the octopus. The plate was a little too bland but given the quality of the other dishes and cocktails we would eat here again in a heartbeat!

Beautiful setting, fantastic people, amazing food. We enjoyed ourselves very much. Great wine list and knowledgable staff to navigate pairings from appetizers through to dessert. The Spotify playlist is off the hook too. Great place for a romantic date or an evening out with friends. Highly recommend this place and we will definitely visit again.

THE BEST LOBSTER ROLL I EVER HAD.The service was outstanding. For starters, we (a party of four) did not have a reservation. However we were accommodated by being seated immediately at the bar. As we deliberated over the drinks, Mitch shared his in depth expertise regarding the wine selection and more. The entire staff was friendly. Furthermore the music and ambience was matchless. Next time we visit Montreal the plan is to patronize Bocata daily.Ralph and Nicole Curtis from New Jersey:-)

People are genuinely at your service.  A bible of cocktails to please. If it's not on there,  the knowledgeable bartender is more than happy to accommodate. Music and ambience is by far my favorite in ville marie. The table skills are on point. Kudos!Make sure you have reservation for table or chance it at the 8 ish seat bar.

The ambiance of this restaurant is super charming and the service was great. My husband and I had some wine, split the Burrata, beef tartare, and octopus appetizers and he ordered the lobster roll and I got the squid ink risotto. The burrata was amazing and was from a local farm and served with anchovies and warm bread - delicious! The octopus was just ok. It was seasoned with paprika and served with potatoes and an aioli sauce. It was not Bad but nothing memorable either. The beef tartare was good, but the chunks of beef were bigger than typical for tartare and seasoning very European but yummy. the squid ink risotto was so/so. It's a heavy dish and was mixed with some sort of aioli sauce and came with cherry tomatoes peas seafood and chorizo. The seafood/meat was all good but the risotto pasta was undercooked and sauce was very heavy and too rich. My husband like the lobster roll - said It was good but not great. Overall food is good, and ambiance is great. I personally would not return for the food but loved the charm of the restaurant's atmosphere!

We had intended to go to Olive et Gourmando down the street, but the line was out the door. Hard pass. We went to the first place we saw that was open and had eggs and were not disappointed at all. Very cozy place, friendly servers, and the food was just what we wanted. I had the shakshuka with poached eggs and chickpeas and my husband had a great Old Montreal breakfast with maple baked beans and maple bacon that was thick-cut and cooked perfectly. The portions were just the right size. We tried the beignets, too, but they were only okay. Coffee was stellar. Sidenote: my husband is Indian, so when he asked for hot sauce, the server must've seen the deflated/insulted look on his face when they put a little bottle of Tabasco in front of him and immediately returned with some Scotch Bonnet West Indian thing that made him smile big. (I'm not a super spicy fan, but even I liked it.) Nicely done!
